facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 66 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 66 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 31st December 1953 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 540 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 31st December, 1953 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 540 of 1953,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated 14th September 1953 of Court of Special Judge Amritsar in Corruption Case No. 13/1-10/3 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 14th September, 1953, of the Court of Special Judge, Amritsar, in Corruption Case No. 13/1-10/3 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant Jaswant Singh prosecuted for receiving illegal gratification as Patwari Fatehpur Rajputan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was prosecuted for receiving illegal gratification and the charge against him was in the following terms That, you, Jaswant Singh, while employed as a Patwari, Fatehpur Rajputan

facts.text: Jaswant Singh received Rs. 50 on 19-3-1953 at Subzi Mandi Amritsar from Pal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: that you received in the sum of Rs. 50 on 19-3-1953 at Subzi Mandi Amritsar from Pal Singh P. W. as a reward for forwarding the application

facts.text: Payment for helping Santa Singh father of Pal Singh in allotment of Ahata No. 10 at village Fatehpur Rajputan.

anchor.surface_text: Es. A. with your recommendation for helping Santa Singh father of Pal Singh in the allotment of Ahata No. 10 situate at village Fatehpur Rajputan

facts.text: Special Judge found appellant accepted illegal gratification from Pal Singh, Hazara Singh, Harnam Singh, Joginder Singh, Atma Singh, Hari Singh and Ganda Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge found that the appellant had accepted illegal gratification from Pal Singh, Hazara Singh, Harnam Singh, Joginder Singh, Atma Singh, Hari Singh and Ganda Singh

facts.text: Special Judge held charge under section 5(1)(a) of Prevention of Corruption Act 1947 established beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: He then held The charge under section 5  1  a  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, has been established against him beyond reasonable doubt.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the High Court of the Punjab

facts.text: Dulat J. of Punjab High Court held sanction valid for Rs. 50 from Pal Singh, upheld conviction but reduced sentence to period undergone.

anchor.surface_text: and Dulat J. held that taking into companysideration the sanction which will be quoted hereinafter The appellant companyld neither have been charged number companyvicted of what is probably a much graver offence of habitually accepting bribes. But he held that sanction was valid qua the charge of accepting illegal gratification of Rs. 50 from Pal Singh.

facts.text: Sanction given by N. N. Kashyap, Esquire I.C.S. Deputy Commissioner, Asr.

anchor.surface_text: Now therefore, 1, N. N. Kashyap, Esquire I.C.S. Deputy Commissioner, Asr, as required by Section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act of 1947, hereby sanction the prosecution

facts.text: Sanction for prosecution of Jaswant Singh Patwari son of Gurdial Singh Kamboh of village Ajaibwali for accepting Rs. 50 from Pal Singh son of S. Santa Singh of village Fatehpur Rajputan.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas I am satisfied that Jaswant Singh Patwari son of Gurdial Singh Kamboh of village Ajaibwali had accepted an illegal gratification of Rs. 50 in 5 currency numberes of Rs. 10 denomination each from one Pal Singh son of S. Santa Singh of village Fatehpur Rajputan,

facts.text: Sanction specifies offence under Section 5 of Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: the said S. Jaswant Singh Patwari had companymitted an offence under Section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 25, 1957 by KAPUR J.

anchor.surface_text: Shaukat Hussain, for the appellant. Gopal Singh and T. M. Sen, for the respondent. 1957. October 25. The following judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held sanction valid only for single offence of receiving Rs. 50 from Pal Singh, not for habitual acceptance.

issues.text: What is the validity and effect of the sanction given under s. 6(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act?

anchor.surface_text: is the validity and effect of the sanction given under s. 6 1  of the Prevention of Corruption Act  Act 2 of 1947 , hereinafter termed the Act.

issues.text: Whether, as the sanction was confined to illegal gratification of Rs. 50 from Pal Singh while the charge was for habitually accepting illegal gratification under section 5(1)(a), the trial was without jurisdiction and the appellant could not be convicted even for the sanctioned offence?

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised by the appellant in this court is that as the sanction was confined to illegal gratification of Rs. 50 paid by Pal Singh and the charge was for habitually accepting illegal gratification the trial was without jurisdiction and the appellant could not be convicted even for the offence which was mentioned in the sanction.

issues.text: Whether the sanction was only for an offence under s. 5(1)(d) and therefore the prosecution, charge and conviction should have been under that provision, rendering the trial under s. 5(1)(a) wholly void?

anchor.surface_text: The contention comes to this that as the sanction was only for receiving Rs. 50 as illegal gratification from Pal Singh and therefore an offence under s. 5 1  d  the prosecution, the charge and conviction should have been under that provision and had that been so there would have been no defect in the jurisdiction of the court trying the case nor any defect in the conviction but as the appellant was tried under the charge of being a habitual receiver of bribes and the sanction was only for one single act of receiving illegal gratification the trial was wholly void as it was a trial by a court without jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether a trial for two offences requiring sanction is wholly void where sanction is granted for one offence but not the other?

anchor.surface_text: The contention that a trial for two offences requiring sanction is wholly void, where the sanction is granted for one offence and not for the other, is in our opinion unsustainable.

issues.text: Whether the evidence in support of being habitually a receiver of bribes caused serious prejudice to the defence of the appellant?

anchor.surface_text: The submission next raised is that the evidence in support of being habitually a receiver of bribes has caused serious prejudice to the defence of the appellant but no such prejudice has been shown nor does the judgment of the High Court which has proceeded on the evidence in support of the charge of Pal Singhs transaction, indicate the existence of any prejudice
